repnme.cdata!: Sierra Leone - National Social Action Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Social Action
            Project for Sierra Leone were as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; bank
            performance was satisfactory; and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. This project performance assessment
            report reviews the experience and lessons from two
            operations in Sierra Leone - the National Social Action
            Project (2003-10), and the food crisis response development
            policy grant (2008-09). The original objectives of this
            project assist war affected communities to restore
            infrastructure and services and build local capacity for
            collective action. Priority would be given to areas not
            previously serviced by the government, newly accessible
            areas, and the most vulnerable population groups within
            those areas.

repnme.cdata!: Sierra Leone - National Social Action Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Social Action
            Project for Sierra Leone were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            pilot rural public works program proved very useful in
            laying the foundation for International Development
            Association (IDA) to respond promptly to evolving country
            priorities and scale up safety nets support in the face of
            shocks. This underscored the importance of having scalable
            safety nets systems in place before the onset of shocks in
            order to respond effectively and in a well-targeted manner.
            In fragile states, requiring counterpart funding from
            Government can be counter-productive, especially when other
            forms of ensuring government ownership are possible.
            Government provision of counterpart funding became a problem
            soon after the project commenced, as noted in the 2005
            Country Portfolio Performance Review (CPPR). Government
            displayed other signs of ownership, and implementation will
            have proceeded more smoothly with 100 percent Bank
            financing. The implementation of a sustained and tailored
            capacity building program was important in fostering
            community participation with local government in all stages
            of the subproject cycle in a post conflict environment. The
            creation of Project Management Committees (PMCs) served as a
            catalyst in mobilizing communities to effectively
            participate and perform their oversight and monitoring
            functions. This in turn strengthened a sense of ownership
            and led to sustained support to operations and maintenance.
            The restoration of infrastructure and essential services, in
            addition to their own merits, also generated social benefits
            by promoting cohesiveness, rebuilding trust and fostering
            community engagement.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Restoring access to basic
            services in a post-war

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            restoring the access to basic services in a post-war Sierra
            Leone. Sierra Leone emerged from a ten year civil war in
            2002 with most of its basic infrastructure in ruins,
            particularly in the rebel-held areas. Following the war, it
            had the lowest Human Development Index in the world. The
            National Social Action Project (NSAP) was designed to
            provide an immediate and a tangible response to the gaps in
            basic service availability, with the priority on the areas
            and populations most affected by the war. The project was
            set to maximize the capacities of local civil society,
            communities and local governments. NSAP had restored
            infrastructure and services, and built capacity for
            collective action in war-affected and poor communities in
            Sierra Leone. Over 7 million people had gained access to
            health facilities, 3.6 million children to educational
            facilities, and over 1.15 million people to economic
            infrastructure such as markets. In addition, an emergency
            Cash-for-Work program was introduced as a new component in
            the project, and as a response to food price increases. Over
            30,000 people, including unemployed youth, female-headed
            households and vulnerable rural and urban households were
            benefitted from the program. NSAP was successful in driving
            significant increases in access to services for
            beneficiaries, and mitigating risks of renewed conflict at
            the level of communities.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Co-financing of the National
            Social Action Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Co-financing of the
            National Social Action Project  for Sierra Leone is to
            assist war-affected or otherwise vulnerable communities to
            restore infrastructure and services, build local capacity
            for collective action, and assist vulnerable households to
            access temporary employment opportunities, with priority
            given to areas not previously serviced by the government,
            newly accessible areas (those which were under rebel control
            until January 2002), food insecure areas, and the most
            vulnerable population groups within those areas. The
            rationale behind the co-financing will be to capitalize on
            the solid performance of the International Development
            Association (IDA)-funded National Social Action Project
            (NSAP) to put in place and scale up safety net interventions
            to help the poor cope with the drastic increases in food
            prices in Sierra Leone. Global food prices have increased 26
            percent over 2004 - 2007, and food crop prices are expected
            to remain above 2004 levels through 2015. The average export
            price for rice, for example, increased from US$375 per
            metric ton in January 2008 to US$775 per metric ton by June
            2008. In Sierra Leone, rice is the main staple food in both
            urban and rural areas; furthermore, the country produces
            only two thirds of the national consumption (355,000 metric
            tons per year), with the shortfall sourced though imports
            and food aid. As such, Sierra Leone is particularly
            vulnerable to rising food prices and the Food and
            Agriculture Organization (FAO) has listed Sierra Leone as
            one of the eight most vulnerable food deficient low income
            countries globally in the current food prices crisis.

docna.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Co-financing of the National
            Social Action Project : additional financing
